29.21: along with their grain offering and their drink offerings for the bulls, the rams, and the lambs, according to the amount specified for each of them;
29.22: also present one male goat for a sin offering, in addition to the regular burnt offering with its grain and drink offerings.
29.23: On the fourth day you are to present ten bulls, two rams, fourteen one-year-old male lambs—all without defect—
29.24: along with their grain offering and their drink offerings for the bulls, the rams, and the lambs, according to the amount specified for each of them;
29.25: also present one male goat for a sin offering, in addition to the regular burnt offering with its grain and drink offerings.
29.26: On the fifth day you are to present nine bulls, two rams, fourteen one-year-old male lambs—all without defect—
29.27: along with their grain offering and their drink offerings for the bulls, the rams, and the lambs, according to the amount specified for each of them;
29.28: also present one male goat for a sin offering, in addition to the regular burnt offering with its grain and drink offerings.
29.29: On the sixth day you are to present eight bulls, two rams, fourteen one-year-old male lambs—all without defect—
29.30: along with their grain offering and their drink offerings for the bulls, the rams, and the lambs, according to the amount specified for each of them;
29.31: also present one male goat for a sin offering, in addition to the regular burnt offering with its grain and drink offerings.
29.32: On the seventh day you are to present seven bulls, two rams, fourteen one-year-old male lambs—all without defect—
29.33: along with their grain offering and their drink offerings for the bulls, the rams, and the lambs, according to the amount specified for each of them;
29.34: also present one male goat for a sin offering, in addition to the regular burnt offering with its grain and drink offerings.
29.35: On the eighth day you shall hold a closing ceremony. You shall not do any of your regular work.
29.36: You are to present a burnt offering, an offering made by fire, with a pleasing aroma to the Lord: one bull, one ram, seven one-year-old male lambs—all without defect—
29.37: along with their grain offering and their drink offerings for the bull, the ram, and the lambs, according to the amount specified for each of them;
29.38: also present one male goat for a sin offering, in addition to the regular burnt offering with its grain and drink offerings.
29.39: In addition to your offerings to fulfill a vow and freewill offerings, you shall prepare these for the Lord at your appointed times as your burnt offerings, your grain offerings, your drink offerings, and your fellowship offerings.
29.40: Moses told the Israelites everything that the Lord commanded Moses.

30.1: Moses also gave the heads of the Israelite tribes these commands from the Lord:
30.2: When a man makes a vow to the Lord or swears an oath to put himself under an obligation, he must not break his word. He must do everything that has come out of his mouth.
30.3: When a woman, while living in her father’s house during her youth, makes a vow to the Lord and puts herself under an obligation,
30.4: and her father hears about her vow and her obligation which she has undertaken, but her father says nothing to her, then all her vows will stand, and every obligation which she has undertaken will stand.
30.5: But if her father forbids her on the same day that he hears about them, none of her vows nor her obligations which she has undertaken will stand. The Lord will forgive her, because her father has forbidden her.
30.6: If she marries a husband while she is obligated by a vow or something she spoke rashly,
30.7: and her husband hears about it but says nothing to her on the same day that he hears about it, then her vows will stand, and her obligations which she has undertaken will be binding.
30.8: But if her husband forbids her on the same day that he hears about it, he will nullify her vow which obligates her and her responsibility for the things she spoke rashly. The Lord will forgive her.
30.9: But the vow of a widow or a divorced woman, every obligation which she put herself under, will be binding on her.
30.10: If, while she is still in her husband’s house, she took a vow or put herself under an obligation with an oath,
30.11: and her husband hears about it but says nothing to her and does not forbid her, then all her vows will stand, and every obligation under which she has put herself will stand.
30.12: But if her husband does indeed nullify them on the same day that he hears about them, then whatever came from her lips concerning her vows or her obligation will not stand. Her husband has nullified them. The Lord will forgive her.
30.13: Her husband may allow or nullify every vow or every oath in which she undertakes an obligation to deny herself.
30.14: But if her husband indeed says nothing to her from day to day, then he confirms all her vows or all her obligations, which are binding on her. He has allowed them, because he said nothing to her on the day that he hears about them.
30.15: But if he nullifies them later than the day he hears about them, then he will bear her responsibility.
30.16: These are the statutes which the Lord commanded Moses about vows pertaining to a husband and his wife, or a father and his daughter during her youth while she still lives at her father’s house.

31.2: “Take vengeance against the Midianites for the Israelites. After that, you will be gathered to your people.”
31.3: Moses spoke to the people, “Equip some of your men for combat. They will go against Midian to carry out the Lord’s vengeance on Midian.
31.4: Send one thousand men from each of the tribes of Israel into combat.”
31.5: So out of all the thousands of Israel, a military unit of a thousand was selected from each tribe—a total of twelve thousand men armed for battle.
31.6: Moses sent them into combat, one thousand from each tribe. Moses sent them and Phinehas, the son of Eleazar the priest, into combat. Things from the sanctuary and the trumpets for signaling were in his hand.
31.7: They fought against Midian, as the Lord commanded Moses, and they killed every male.
31.8: Along with the others who were slain, they killed the kings of Midian: Evi, Rekem, Zur, Hur, and Reba, the five kings of Midian. They also killed Balaam son of Beor with the sword.
31.9: The Israelites took the women of Midian and their children captive. They plundered all their animals, property, and possessions.
31.10: They burned all their cities where they settled and all their camps.
31.11: They took all the plunder and all the spoils of war, both people and animals.
31.12: They brought the captives, the spoils of war, and the plunder to Moses, Eleazar the priest, and the Israelite community at the camp on the Plains of Moab, which was by the Jordan across from Jericho.
31.13: Moses, Eleazar the priest, and all the tribal chiefs of the community went out to meet them outside of the camp.
31.14: Moses was angry with the officers of the army—the commanders of thousands and the commanders of hundreds—who were coming back from the military campaign.
31.15: Moses said to them, “Have you allowed every woman to live?
31.16: Look, following Balaam’s advice, these women were the ones who incited the Israelites to be unfaithful to the Lord in the Peor incident, and so the plague came upon the community of the Lord.
31.17: Now, kill every male among the children, and kill every woman who has had sexual relations with a man.
31.18: But you may keep alive for yourselves all the young females who have not had sexual relations with a man.
31.19: “All of you who have killed a person or touched a slain body shall stay outside of the camp for seven days. Purify yourselves and your captives on the third day and on the seventh day.
31.20: Also purify every garment, every leather item, everything made of goat hair, and every item of wood.”
31.21: Eleazar the priest said to the soldiers who had gone into battle, “These are the regulations which the Lord has commanded Moses:
31.22: The gold, silver, bronze, iron, tin, and lead
31.23: (everything that can withstand fire) you must be sure to pass through the fire, and it will be clean. It also is to be purified with the water for removing impurity. Everything that cannot withstand fire, you are to pass through the water.
31.24: You shall wash your clothes on the seventh day, and you will be clean. After that, you may come into the camp.”
31.26: “You, Eleazar the priest, and the leading fathers of the community are to count the spoils of war—the captives, both people and animals—
31.27: and divide the spoils of war into two equal parts: one part for the troops who went out for combat and one for all the rest of the community.
31.28: Raise a tribute to the Lord to be given by the fighting men who went out for battle. Take one out of every five hundred from the people, the cattle, the donkeys, and the flocks.
31.29: Take it from the fighting men’s half, and give it to Eleazar the priest as an elevated offering to the Lord.
31.30: Also from the Israelites’ half, you will take one out of every fifty from the people, the cattle, the donkeys, the flocks, and all the animals, and give them to the Levites, who attend to the duties at the Lord’s Dwelling.”
31.31: Moses and Eleazar the priest did as the Lord commanded Moses.
31.32: Now the spoils of war remaining from the plunder that the army took was 675,000 animals from the flocks,
31.35: and 32,000 people in all, that is, the women who had not had sexual relations with a man.
31.36: The half share for those who went out into combat numbered 337,500 animals from the flocks,
31.37: and the tribute for the Lord from the flocks was 675.
31.38: The cattle numbered 36,000; the tribute for the Lord was 72.
31.39: The donkeys numbered 30,500; the tribute for the Lord was 61.
31.40: The people numbered 16,000; the tribute for the Lord was 32 people.
31.41: Moses gave the tribute, the elevated offering to the Lord, to Eleazar the priest as the Lord commanded Moses.
31.42: From the Israelites’ half, which Moses set aside from the share of the men who fought,
31.43: the community’s half share was 337,500 animals from the flocks,
31.47: From the Israelites’ half share Moses took one out of every fifty from the people and the animals and gave them to the Levites, who attended to the duties at the Lord’s Dwelling, as the Lord commanded Moses.
31.48: The officers who were over the units of a thousand in the army—the commanders of thousands and the commanders of hundreds—approached Moses.
31.49: They said to Moses, “Your servants have taken a head count of the fighting men who were under our command, and not one of them is missing.
31.50: So we have brought as an offering to the Lord the gold items which every man acquired—armlets, bracelets, signet rings, earrings, and necklaces—to make atonement for ourselves before the Lord.”
31.51: Moses and Eleazar the priest accepted the gold from them, all the crafted items.
31.52: All the gold from the elevated offering that the commanders of thousands and the commanders of hundreds lifted up to the Lord amounted to 16,750 shekels.
31.53: Each of the soldiers had taken plunder for himself.
31.54: Moses and Eleazar the priest accepted the gold from the commanders of thousands and hundreds and brought it into the Tent of Meeting as a memorial for the Israelites before the Lord.

32.1: The descendants of Reuben and Gad had very large flocks and herds of livestock. They saw that the land of Jazer and the land of Gilead was ideal for livestock.
32.2: The descendants of Gad and Reuben came and spoke to Moses, Eleazar the priest, and the tribal chiefs of the community. They said,
32.3: “Ataroth, Dibon, Jazer, Nimrah, Heshbon, Elealeh, Sebam, Nebo, and Beon—
32.4: the land which the Lord struck down before the community of Israel—is an ideal land for livestock. We, your servants, have livestock.”
32.5: They continued, “If we have found favor in your eyes, let this land be given to your servants as a possession. Do not require us to cross the Jordan.”
32.6: Moses said to the descendants of Gad and Reuben, “Do you expect your brothers to go into battle while you live here?
32.7: Why are you disheartening the Israelites from crossing over into the land which the Lord has given to them?
32.8: Your fathers did that same thing when I sent them from Kadesh Barnea to see the land.
32.9: They had gone up as far as the Valley of Eshcol and had seen the land. Then they disheartened the Israelites so that they would not go into the land which the Lord had given them.
32.10: The Lord’s anger burned on that day, and he swore an oath,
32.11: ‘Surely none of the men twenty years old and up who came up from Egypt will see the land which I swore to give to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, because they have not followed me completely,
32.12: except Caleb son of Jephunneh the Kenizzite and Joshua son of Nun, because they have followed the Lord completely.’
32.13: The Lord’s anger burned against Israel so he made them wander in the wilderness for forty years, until the entire generation that had done evil in the Lord’s sight was gone.”
32.14: He continued, “See, here you are, a band of sinners standing in your fathers’ place, adding still more to the Lord’s fierce anger against Israel.
32.15: If you turn away from following him, he will once again leave these people in the wilderness, and you will have destroyed all these people.”
32.16: They approached him and said, “We will build sheep pens here for our livestock and cities for our children,
32.17: but we will be quick to arm ourselves to go ahead of the Israelites until we have brought them to their own places. Our children will live in our fortified cities because of the inhabitants of the land,
32.18: but we will not return to our houses until the Israelites have each taken possession of their inheritance.
32.19: We certainly will not have any claim to an inheritance with them on the other side of the Jordan, because our inheritance has come to us here on the east side of the Jordan, toward the sunrise.”
32.20: Moses said to them, “If you will do what you have said, if you will arm yourselves before the Lord for battle,
32.21: and if every one of you who is armed will cross over the Jordan before the Lord until he has driven out his enemies before him,
32.22: and until the land has been subdued before the Lord, then after that you may return home. You will be guiltless toward the Lord and Israel. This land will be a possession for you in the presence of the Lord.
32.23: “But if you will not do this, look, you will have sinned against the Lord. Know that your sin will find you out.
32.24: Build cities for your children, and pens for your flocks, but keep the promises that have come out of your mouth.”
32.25: The descendants of Gad and Reuben spoke to Moses: “We, your servants, will do as my lord commands.
32.26: Our children, our wives, our livestock, and all our animals will stay here by the cities of Gilead,
32.27: but your servants, every man who is armed for war, will cross over before the Lord for battle, as my lord says.”
32.28: So Moses gave a command concerning them to Eleazar the priest, Joshua son of Nun, and the leading fathers of the Israelite tribes.
32.29: Moses said to them, “If the descendants of Gad and Reuben, everyone who is armed for battle, will cross over the Jordan with you before the Lord, and the land is subdued before you, then you will give them the land of Gilead as a possession.
32.30: But if they are not willing to cross over with you armed, they will have an inheritance among you in the land of Canaan.”
32.31: The descendants of Gad and Reuben answered, “We will do what the Lord has said to us, your servants.
32.32: We will cross over armed before the Lord into the land of Canaan, but the property that comes to us as our inheritance will be east of the Jordan.”
32.33: Moses gave the kingdom of Sihon king of the Amorites and the kingdom of Og king of Bashan to the descendants of Gad, to the descendants of Reuben, and to half of the tribe descended from Manasseh, the son of Joseph—the land including its cities with the territories surrounding them.
32.34: The descendants of Gad rebuilt Dibon, Ataroth, Aroer,
32.36: Beth Nimrah, and Beth Haran as fortified cities and built sheep pens there.
32.37: The descendants of Reuben built up Heshbon, Elealeh, Kiriathaim,
32.38: Nebo and Baal Meon (their names were changed), and Sibmah. They gave names to the cities they rebuilt.
32.39: The descendants of Makir, the son of Manasseh, went to Gilead, captured it, and drove out the Amorites who were there.
32.40: Moses gave Gilead to the clan of Makir, the descendants of Manasseh, and they lived there.
32.41: Jair, a descendant of Manasseh, went and captured their villages and called them Havvoth Jair.
32.42: Nobah went and captured Kenath and its settlements. He renamed it Nobah after himself.

33.1: These were the stages in the Israelites’ journey when they went out from the land of Egypt, lined up according to their military units, under the leadership of Moses and Aaron.
33.2: At the command of the Lord, Moses recorded their departure locations according to the stages in their journey. These were the stages in their journey listed by their departure locations:
33.3: They set out from Rameses in the first month, on the fifteenth day of the first month, the day after the Passover. The Israelites went out defiantly in the sight of all the Egyptians,
33.4: while the Egyptians were burying all their firstborn, whom the Lord had struck down among them. The Lord also brought judgment on their gods.
33.5: The Israelites set out from Rameses and camped at Sukkoth.
33.6: They set out from Sukkoth and camped at Etham, which is on the edge of the wilderness.
33.7: They set out from Etham and turned back to Pi Hahiroth, which faces Baal Zephon. They camped in front of Migdol.
33.8: They set out from Pi Hahiroth and crossed through the middle of the sea into the wilderness. They traveled for three days in the Wilderness of Etham and camped at Marah.
33.9: They set out from Marah and came to Elim. At Elim there were twelve springs of water and seventy palm trees. They camped there.
33.10: They set out from Elim and camped by the Red Sea.
33.11: They set out from the Red Sea and camped in the Wilderness of Sin.
33.12: They set out from the Wilderness of Sin and camped at Dophkah.
33.13: They set out from Dophkah and camped at Alush.
33.14: They set out from Alush and camped at Rephidim, where there was no water for the people to drink.
33.15: They set out from Rephidim and camped in the Wilderness of Sinai.
33.16: They set out from the Wilderness of Sinai and camped at Kibroth Hatta’avah.
33.17: They set out from Kibroth Hatta’avah and camped at Hazeroth.
33.18: They set out from Hazeroth and camped at Rithmah.
33.19: They set out from Rithmah and camped at Rimmon Perez.
33.20: They set out from Rimmon Perez and camped at Libnah.
33.21: They set out from Libnah and camped at Rissah.
33.22: They set out from Rissah and camped at Kehelathah.
33.23: They set out from Kehelathah and camped at Mount Shepher.
33.24: They set out from Mount Shepher and camped at Haradah.
33.25: They set out from Haradah and camped at Makheloth.
33.26: They set out from Makheloth and camped at Tahath.
33.27: They set out from Tahath and camped at Terah.
33.28: They set out from Terah and camped at Mithkah.
33.29: They set out from Mithkah and camped at Hashmonah.
33.30: They set out from Hashmonah and camped at Moseroth.
33.31: They set out from Moseroth and camped at Bene Ja’akan.
33.32: They set out from Bene Ja’akan and camped at Hor Haggidgad.
33.33: They set out from Hor Haggidgad and camped at Jotbathah.
33.34: They set out from Jotbathah and camped at Abronah.
33.35: They set out from Abronah and camped at Ezion Geber.
33.36: They set out from Ezion Geber and camped in the Wilderness of Zin, that is, at Kadesh.
33.37: They set out from Kadesh and camped at Mount Hor, on the edge of the land of Edom.
33.38: Aaron the priest went up onto Mount Hor at the Lord’s command and died there in the fortieth year after the Israelites had come out of the land of Egypt, in the fifth month, on the first day of the month.
33.39: Aaron was one hundred twenty-three years old when he died at Mount Hor.
33.40: The Canaanite king of Arad, who lived in the Negev in the land of Canaan, heard that the Israelites were coming.
33.41: They set out from Mount Hor and camped at Zalmonah.
33.42: They set out from Zalmonah and camped at Punon.
33.43: They set out from Punon and camped at Oboth.
33.44: They set out from Oboth and camped at Iye Abarim, on the border of Moab.
33.45: They set out from Iyim and camped at Dibon Gad.
33.46: They set out from Dibon Gad and camped at Almon Diblathaim.
33.47: They set out from Almon Diblathaim and camped by the mountains of the Abarim range, near Nebo.
33.48: They set out from the mountains of Abarim and camped on the Plains of Moab by the Jordan across from Jericho.
33.49: They camped by the Jordan, from Beth Jeshimoth to Abel Shittim, on the Plains of Moab.
33.50: On the Plains of Moab by the Jordan across from Jericho, the Lord spoke to Moses:
33.51: “Speak to the Israelites and tell them, ‘When you cross the Jordan into the land of Canaan,
33.52: you shall drive out all the inhabitants of the land before you, destroy all their carved images and all their cast idols, and destroy all their high places.
33.53: You shall take possession of the land and settle in it, because I have given the land to you to possess it.
33.54: You shall distribute the land as a possession by lot according to your clans. For a larger clan you shall increase its inheritance. For a smaller clan you shall decrease its inheritance. Wherever the lot falls for that clan, that will be its portion. You will distribute the land as a possession according to the tribes of your fathers.
33.55: But if you do not drive out the inhabitants of the land before you, then those that you allow to remain will become barbs in your eyes and thorns in your sides. They will cause trouble for you in the land where you will settle.
33.56: Then I will do to you what I planned to do to them.’”

34.2:
to deliver these commands to the Israelites:
When you come into the land of Canaan (this is the land that will fall to you as an inheritance, the land of Canaan as defined by its boundaries),
34.3: your southern border will extend from the Wilderness of Zin along the border of Edom. Your southern border on the east will start from the south end of the Dead Sea.
34.4: Your border will turn south of the Ascent of Akrabbim, pass through to Zin, and it will end south of Kadesh Barnea. Then it will go out to Hazar Adda and pass through to Azmon.
34.5: The border will turn from Azmon to the Stream of Egypt, and it will end at the Mediterranean Sea.
34.6: For the western border, you will have the Mediterranean Sea as your border. This will be your western border.
34.7: This will be your northern border: From the Mediterranean Sea you will draw a line for yourselves to Mount Hor.
34.8: From Mount Hor you will draw a line to Lebo Hamath. The end of the border will be at Zedad.
34.9: Then the border will go to Ziphron, and it will end at Hazar Enan. This will be your northern border.
34.10: You will draw a line to serve as your eastern border from Hazar Enan to Shepham.
34.11: The border will go down from Shepham to Riblah, on the east side of Ain. The border will go down and meet the eastern slope of the Sea of Galilee.
34.12: The border will go down to the Jordan and end at the Dead Sea. This will be your land according to its boundaries on all sides.
34.13: Moses commanded the Israelites, “This is the land which you will assign as a possession by lot, which the Lord has commanded you to give to the nine and a half tribes.
34.14: The tribe of Reuben’s descendants according to their fathers’ houses and the tribe of Gad’s descendants according to their fathers’ houses have already received their possession. Also half of the tribe of Manasseh has received its possession.
34.15: The two and a half tribes have received their possession east of the Jordan across from Jericho, toward the sunrise.”
34.17:
These are the names of the men who will assign the land as a possession for you:
Eleazar the priest and Joshua son of Nun.
34.18: You will take one tribal chief from every tribe to assign the land as a possession.
34.19:
These are the names of the men:
Caleb son of Jephunneh from the tribe of Judah;
34.20: Shemuel son of Ammihud from the tribe of Simeon’s descendants;
34.21: Elidad son of Kislon from the tribe of Benjamin;
34.22: Bukki son of Jogli, a tribal chief from the tribe of Dan’s descendants;
34.23: from the sons of Joseph: Hanniel son of Ephod, a tribal chief from the tribe of Manasseh’s descendants;
34.24: Kemuel son of Shiphtan, a tribal chief from the tribe of Ephraim’s descendants;
34.25: Elizaphan son of Parnak, a tribal chief from the tribe of Zebulun’s descendants;
34.26: Paltiel son of Azzan, a tribal chief from the tribe of Issachar’s descendants;
34.27: Ahihud son of Shelomi, a tribal chief from the tribe of Asher’s descendants;
34.28: Pedahel son of Ammihud, a tribal chief from the tribe of Naphtali’s descendants.
34.29: These were the men whom the Lord commanded to assign the areas of possession for the Israelites in the land of Canaan.

35.1: The Lord spoke to Moses on the Plains of Moab by the Jordan across from Jericho:
35.2: Command the people of Israel to give the Levites cities to live in from the territory assigned to them as their possession. They will also give the Levites the pasturelands around those cities.
35.3: The Levites will then have cities to live in. Their pasturelands will be for their cattle, their flocks and herds, and all their other animals.
35.4: The pasturelands of the cities, which you will give to the Levites, will extend out from the wall of the city 500 yards in all directions.
35.5: As the eastern boundary you will measure 1000 yards in addition to the size of the city, 1000 yards as the southern boundary, 1000 yards as the western boundary, and 1000 yards as the northern boundary. The city is in the middle. This area will serve as the pasturelands of their cities.
35.6: The cities which you will give to the Levites will include six cities of refuge, which you will provide so that a person who has killed someone may flee there. In addition to these six cities, you will give them forty-two other cities.
35.7: All the cities which you are to give to the Levites will total forty-eight cities along with their pasturelands.
35.8: For the cities which you will transfer to the Levites from the property of the Israelites, you will take more cities from a larger tribe and fewer from a smaller tribe. Every tribe will give some of its cities to the Levites in proportion to the amount of assigned territory it has received.
35.10:
to speak to the Israelites and tell them this:
When you cross the Jordan into the land of Canaan,
35.11: you are to designate some cities to be cities of refuge for yourselves, so that a person who has killed someone by taking someone’s life unintentionally may flee there.
35.12: The cities will serve as a refuge for you from the avenger, so that a person who has killed someone will not die until he stands trial before the community.
35.13: The cities which you will set aside will serve as the six cities of refuge for you.
35.14: You are to set aside three cities east of the Jordan and three cities in the land of Canaan. They will serve as cities of refuge.
35.15: These six cities will serve as a refuge for Israelites, for resident aliens, and for temporary residents living among them so that everyone who has taken someone’s life unintentionally may flee there.
35.16: But if a person strikes someone with an iron object so that he dies, that person is a murderer. The murderer must certainly be put to death.
35.17: If a person strikes someone with a stone in his hand that could kill someone, and the victim dies, that person is a murderer. The murderer must certainly be put to death.
35.18: Or if a person strikes someone with a wooden object in his hand that could kill someone, and the victim dies, that person is a murderer. The murderer must certainly be put to death.
35.19: The avenger of blood himself will put the murderer to death. When he apprehends him, he is to put him to death.
35.20: If a person pushes someone out of hatred or throws something at him with malicious intent so that he dies,
35.21: or in hostility strikes him with his hand so that he dies, that person who struck him must certainly be put to death. He is a murderer. The avenger of blood is to put the murderer to death when he apprehends him.
35.22: But if a person pushes someone suddenly without hostility or throws any object at him without malicious intent,
35.23: or if without looking he drops a stone on someone big enough to kill him and that person dies, since that person was not his enemy, and he did not seek to harm him,
35.24: the community will judge between the killer and the avenger of blood according to these ordinances.
35.25: The community will deliver the person who has killed someone from the hand of the avenger of blood. Then the community will take him back to his city of refuge, to which he had fled. He must live there until the death of the high priest, who was anointed with the holy oil.
35.26: But if the person who has killed someone ever goes outside of the border of the city of refuge to which he has fled,
35.27: and the avenger of blood finds him outside of the border of his city of refuge, and the avenger of blood kills the person who has killed someone, the avenger will not be guilty of bloodshed,
35.28: because the person who has killed someone should have stayed in his city of refuge until the death of the high priest. But after the death of the high priest he may return to the land that is his possession.
35.29: These things will be a legal statute for you throughout your generations wherever you live.
35.30: Everyone who has taken someone’s life is to be put to death as a murderer on the testimony of witnesses, but no one is to die on the testimony of only one witness.
35.31: You are not to accept a ransom for the life of a murderer who is guilty of death, because he must certainly be put to death.
35.32: You are not to accept a ransom for the one who has fled to a city of refuge in order to allow him to return to live in his land before the death of the priest.
35.33: So you are not to pollute the land where you are, because bloodshed pollutes the land. No atonement can be made for the land where blood has been shed except by the blood of the one who shed it.
35.34: You are not to defile the land in which you are living, where I am dwelling in its midst, for I, the Lord, am dwelling in the midst of the people of Israel.

36.1: The leading fathers of the clan of the descendants of Gilead, the son of Makir, the son of Manasseh, from the clans of the sons of Joseph, approached Moses and spoke to Moses and the tribal chiefs, the heads of the fathers’ houses of the people of Israel.
36.2: They said, “The Lord commanded my lord to assign the land for the Israelites’ inheritance by lot. My lord was commanded by the Lord to give the inheritance of Zelophehad our brother to his daughters.
36.3: Now, if they marry any of the men from the other Israelite tribes, then their inheritance would be taken away from our ancestral inheritance and would be added to the inheritance of the tribe into which they married. So part of our allotted inheritance would be taken away.
36.4: When the Jubilee occurs for the Israelites, that inheritance would be added to the inheritance of the tribe into which they married. Therefore that inheritance will be taken away from the inheritance of our ancestral tribe.”
36.5: Then at the Lord’s word, Moses commanded the Israelites, “What the tribe of Joseph’s descendants is saying is right.
36.6: This is what the Lord commands for Zelophehad’s daughters: They may be married to whomever they wish, but they are to be married within the clan of their father’s tribe.
36.7: In that way no inheritance for the Israelites will transfer from tribe to tribe, for each of the Israelites is to keep the inheritance of his ancestral tribe.
36.8: Every daughter who possesses an inheritance in any of the Israelite tribes is to be married to someone from the clan of her father’s tribe, so that each of the Israelites will retain possession of the inheritance of his fathers.
36.9: So no inheritance will transfer from one tribe to another tribe, for each of the Israelite tribes will keep its own inheritance.”
36.10: So Zelophehad’s daughters did as the Lord commanded Moses.
36.11: Zelophehad’s daughters—Mahlah, Tirzah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Noah—were married to cousins on their father’s side.
36.12: They were married to men from the clans of the descendants of Manasseh the son of Joseph. Their inheritance remained within the tribe of their father’s clan.
36.13: These are the commands and the ordinances which the Lord commanded through Moses for the Israelites on the Plains of Moab near the Jordan across from Jericho.
